item.title: The Correction
item.description:
Her daughter said “supposably” and she didn’t fix it.

This was new. For thirty-one years she had been fixing things â€” the pronunciation of “nuclear,” the misuse of “literally,” the picture frames that drifted two degrees left in the hallway every time someone walked past too fast. She’d been an editor at a university press for most of those years, which people thought explained it. It didn’t. The editing was a symptom, not a cause. The cause was that wrongness had a sound, like a smoke detector with a dying battery, and she was the only one who could hear it.
